title: Portrait of a Young Woman

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on canvas.

description: This young woman’s direct gaze and parted lips lend her a sense of lively presence, as does her right hand venturing subtly into the viewer’s space. This painting has the appearance of a portrait, but the fanciful costume and casual pose suggest that it could be a character study. Such works, which were pioneered by Rembrandt van Rijn and taken up by his pupils, were sold on the open market at significantly lower prices than commissioned portraits. One of Rembrandt’s last students around 1660, Aert de Gelder continued to use his teacher’s techniques to achieve richly textured surfaces and psychological depth into the 18th century, well after Rembrandt’s popularity had faded.
publication_history:
Kurt Bauch, “Ausstellung Holländischer Kunst von 1450–1900 in London,” Zeitschrift für bildende Kunst, 63 (1929–30), p. 20. 

Art Institute of Chicago, Report for the Year 1932 (Chicago, 1933), pp. 18, 35, ill. 

Daniel Catton Rich, “A Portrait by Arent de Gelder,” Bulletin of The Art Institute of Chicago 27, 2 (1933), pp. 34–36, cover ill. 

“Chicago Gets Work by Rembrandt’s Last Pupil,” Art Digest 7, 10 (1933), pp. 27–28, ill. 

Daniel Catton Rich, “Chicago Acquires Arent de Gelder,” Art News 31, 21 (1933), p. 14.

Alfred M. Frankfurter, “Art in the Century of Progress,” Fine Arts 20, 2 (1933), p. 23, ill.

“Chicago Holds Rembrandt Show of Wide Interest,” Art News 34, 14 (1936), p. 5.

The Hague, Pulchri Studio, Collection Goudstikker d’Amsterdam, November 3–December 2, 1923, cat. 35.

Art Institute of Chicago, Rembrandt After Three Hundred Years, October 25–December 7, 1969, no. 68; traveled to The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, December 22, 1969–February 1, 1970; The Detroit Institute of Arts, February 24–April 5, 1970.

Dordrechts Museum, Arent de Gelder (1645–1727): Rembrandts laatste leerling, October 10, 1998–January 17, 1999, no. 28; traveled to Cologne, Wallraf-Richartz-Museum, February 19–May 19, 1999.
provenance_text: Probably Hugh Ker Colville, Bellaport Hall, Shropshire, England [according to London 1929]. Collection D. A. J. Kessler, The Hague [according to St. Louis 1922]. Jacques Goudstikker, Amsterdam, 1922 [lent by him to St. Louis, 1922; acquisition date according to Sutton 2008]. D. A. Hoogendijk, Amsterdam [lent by him to London 1929]; purchased by the Art Institute, 1932.1175.
